Posts.Content: Hi glitzygran, The  M&S soft vests are actually sports bras product code 05982011  they come in 2 part set = black & white or natural & white.  I am a size 38B and I bought size large. £12.50 per pack. I tried on many types of bras but  found them painful as I had a 3 nodes removed and 1 x mastectomy. To put the bra on I step into mine and slide bad arm in then good arm. They are so soft and if my breast swells or have fluid put in as I am going through reconstruction the bra is still very comfortable. I have had a line put in for my chemo just under my breast and the bra does not cause me discomfort. I have been wearing them now for 6months looking forward to going back to wearing a pretty bra but whenever I try they soon have to come of f!!! When you have rads the area becomes very sensitive and needs a gentle covering ie padding and these bras just do that. Oh I also tried to buy the ones advertised on TV which had pretty colours but the seams caused me to get blisters and I had to be put on antibiotics. Surgeon was not too pleased and told me stick to M&S. Hope this helps a little and wish you all the very best with rads and going back to work.  Marie-Francoise
Posts.Title: Prosthesis after lumpectomy

Posts.Content: Happy New Year Sharon,   Wishing you the best with your Gp I was very ill when taking generic Letrozole and oncology asked my doctor to prescribe "Femara made by UK Novatis . Femera is made in numerous European countries packaging is identical but all using different filling compounds and that is what your body is reacting to.  Femara UK Novatis is the one I have been taking for the past 5years, my swelling was reduced my joints hurt less and I am able and enjoy going to the gym once again at 70 I am feeling so much healthier after being bedridden from chemo.  Its good to write a diary of all the problems so you don't forget when your with your GP, he must write on the prescription UK Novatis  as many chemists find it difficult to get that specific one. My local Boots have been brilliant. Wishing you all the very best and a healthier 2019 Marie
Posts.Title: battle of the letrozole brands

Posts.Content: Hi glitzygran, The  M&S soft vests are actually sports bras product code 05982011  they come in 2 part set = black & white or natural & white.  I am a size 38B and I bought size large. £12.50 per pack. I tried on many types of bras but  found them painful as I had a 3 nodes removed and 1 x mastectomy. To put the bra on I step into mine and slide bad arm in then good arm. They are so soft and if my breast swells or have fluid put in as I am going through reconstruction the bra is still very comfortable. I have had a line put in for my chemo just under my breast and the bra does not cause me discomfort. I have been wearing them now for 6months looking forward to going back to wearing a pretty bra but whenever I try they soon have to come of f!!! When you have rads the area becomes very sensitive and needs a gentle covering ie padding and these bras just do that. Oh I also tried to buy the ones advertised on TV which had pretty colours but the seams caused me to get blisters and I had to be put on antibiotics. Surgeon was not too pleased and told me stick to M&S. Hope this helps a little and wish you all the very best with rads and going back to work.  Marie-Francoise
Posts.Title: Prosthesis after lumpectomy

Posts.Content: Hi yesterday was the day 5 years ago I couldn’t imagine would happen but it has I have been discharged with an excellent.  Ok I have a few aches and i’m a little slower and still take one tablet but I am so proud of myself to have done it.  So anybody on the journey however long it looks there is hope that you walk out of the hospital feeling a tad nervous no longer in the amazing care of the amazing Breast Services team whispering I did it because you can’t believe it. Well believe it !!!! Wishing everyone a very fast journey to getting “the all clear” Big gentle hugs Mf
Posts.Title: Cancer free

Posts.Content: Hello Kath  yes its a minefield so many different variations of surgeries and Chemo, I asked the same questions to my surgeon when I tried to hold on to my breast and not have a mastectomy.  My surgeon explained very gently that it all depends how big the breast is, how big the area effected by cancer, how many areas, how large, nodes effected if so how many,.... etc, etc . He convinced me that my treatment was the best for me. My oncologist did the same. Its very confusing, but I learnt to question anything I did not understand.   Reading about peoples experience has helped me to understand what is going to happen next and how I can make it less daunting. Regarding Steriods I was advised to take them early in the day as a if you take them late in the day they keep you awake.  I am also having my first T on Tuesday!!!! Take care and all the very best Marie-Francoise
Posts.Title: Difference in treatments. Why so much! Confused.

Posts.Content: Hello Kay, I understand how you feel...... initially after my mastectomy it was painful/upsetting for me to look in the mirror, but after a while and several examinations and checks that the wounds were alright by my surgeon,nurses and daughter, I soon began to appreciate that all was well but most important the surgery had been successful and if everybody else was happy and pleased why should I feel different. Give yourself time to get used to the change........... Wear clothes that makes you feel comfortable even if you have to treat yourself to something new.........If you have someone close ask is it noticeable and they will tell you and soon it will feel like the question "Does my bum look big in this?" just joking!!!! You do not say how long ago was the surgery and if you had to have chemo......My surgeon advised me not to swim in a swimming pool as you are very susceptible to infections until your immune system is back to normal and the scar completely healed....I really miss my aqua class. But as so many of us have learnt ....... we are warriors with battle scars .....be proud and your children will be soooooo proud of you, have fun and enjoy the summer  holidays with them.  Big gentle hug from Marie-Francoise
Posts.Title: Ashamed/Embarrassed by scar.......

Posts.Content: Hi treacle love the name, i had mastectomy 1st week December arrived in Australia New Years eve soaked up lots of vit D and had a great time with my daughter.  4 Feb came back for chemo ughhh and while sitting in the chair with a lovely glow I thought of the beaches. 9 mnths later no hair no glow no energy I was grateful for that wonderful holiday.  My surgeon and oncologist both agreed and encouraged me to go as long as I was back within 2 months to start the chemo. So I wish you an amazing holiday with your girls, get lots of vit D it will kick start the next part of your treatment. Big gentle hugs  oh im afraid they will have to carry your suitcase. That is a definate no no but I’m sure they wont mind.  Xxx
Posts.Title: can you put treatment on hold for a couple of weeks?

Posts.Content: Well done, enjoy you so deserve lots of joy. Every step I take I think yehhhh sooo happy thats done.....I've done mastectomy.....trip to Australia.....Chemo.....Ambulance to Hospital......end of Chemo ..... painted 7 doors.....Herceptin only 2 more.....been on channel 4 news promoting Nordic Walking .... hair growing nicely even if I do look like a pixie.....reconstruction booked.......only  5 years left of Letrozole.....very busy  9 months. Not quiet there yet but your message tells me "we can all do it" and your right its daunting but very very doable. Big gentle hug to all Marie-Francoise
Posts.Title: I did it!! 😜

Posts.Content: Hi Sophie just a little tip when you pick up your prescription always check that it’s Femara Norvatis Uk, as sometimes you may be given Spanish or Greek Femara and again it will be Letrozole as it should be but the tablet compound will give you problems.  I say sorry to the chemist refuse them and ask them to order in the Uk brand. Your doctor must state Femara Norvatis Uk. On the prescription.  I’m on my 3rd year of taking them and the difference is incredible, it saddens me that so many women who have gone through so much have to argue to get a medication that doesn’t harm them or make them ill. Big gentle hugs and well done  Mf x w
Posts.Title: Letrozole - side effects and supplements

Posts.Content: Good morning Carol well done for organising an appointment sooner than later, we here are here for you to encourage when you get tired.  Ok you joined the BC club I know you didn’t want to but good news is lymph nodes clear and you caught it early. I didn’t not so good but my best friend had same results as you and is doing brilliantly and were back to shopping and grandchildren carering till they drop All the best with appointments and listen to your body when your tired down tools and rest. Oh paint your nails a dark colour chemo and light does strange things to nails (they go black) not a good look except when painted black‍ Go to Mavala site send them an email they will send you info on careing for your nails. Ok big hug I’m off to Ikea with a friend so I feel I’m doing good and so will you xxxxxx
Posts.Title: PICC line or not?

Posts.Content: Hi Emma, I understand how you feel and so many will have felt the same two weeks after surgery still in pain and feeling we have to do things. Unfortunately you have to really listen to your body and and learn "pain management" or you will take soooo much longer to recover and undo what the surgeons have done. My instructions when I was discharged after surgery: When tired rest and I mean rest. Do not wait till your exhausted!!! Exercise  (All in the ward had to greet our surgeon with a salute of putting our hand behind our head)  it made us smile to see him so happy that we could do it and gave us a sense we are getting better.    It also prevents fluid build up which is very painful. Drink plenty of water. Take our painkillers/medication regular  (pain management) as Louise says no medals for pain. (I know I didn't get any) Never carry anything heavy, (When I do !  I suffer afterwards) I am now an online shopper.  No hoovering! house stays clean if your resting. Family and friends love to do it, and they always clear up when in the house. I have been told that they feel so much better that they can help and see you getting stronger. If you just take it easy in the first weeks,    especially,     your healing begins to speed up and you will have less complications. We all have learnt from others and our own experiences. So Emma crunchie time (I like that Louise) Take care  Marie-Francoise
Posts.Title: 2 weeks on. Still just as sore

Posts.Content: Hi Gem, I am so sorry to hear that at 28 you are having to go through this. Ok to use the cold cap or not, I am 65 and was encouraged like you by my oncologist and the nurses on my 1st chemo and I am so happy I did. It wasn't easy and the 1st 15 mins was painful so I would take a paracetamol before putting the cap on, my children helped me through it by trying to make me laugh, and holding my hand. I found hair every morning on my pillow and would just roll it up with a sticky roller.  Also I washed my hair with a chemical free shampoo once a week with cool water (as cool as you can bear it) I found if my head got warm then the hair fell out. I have finished my FEC&T with hair if a little thin, and 4weeks later I have new hair growing that now makes my hair looks thicker. If your hair is long it may be better to cut it shorter. There were a few ladies who also use the cold cap and one lady has lots of hair although she says she has thinned out so it also depends on how thick your hair is to start with. The hospital Charing Cross use Digital a newer machine which brings the temp to  5º , some older machines make it a lot lower so that is something to consider. I had it on 30mins before chemo and 1 1/2 hr after but it will all depend on the machine. I wanted to give up also but now i'm glad I continued its not pleasant but its doable. I'm giving you a gentle hug and whatever you decide all the very best with your chemo. Marie-Francoise
Posts.Title: cold cap??

Posts.Content: Hi if oncology has recommended chemo then you shouldn’t stop because of a picc line trouble. If you are an active person your arm is not the place to fit it as the experience your having is very usual . Perhaps you need a Central line (I think they are called ) inserted just below the collar bone it leaves a tiny scar if you wear low cut dresses but it was fairly normal place at my chemo dept. I had one put just under my bra definitely not a good place as a bra would hurt just by touching it. 11 more  chemo so it’s worth considering where would it be less troublesome for you and I hope they listen and put it there. Wishing you all the very best one day it will be a memory you could have done without but don’t let them turn it into a nightmare tell them my arm is not the right place! Big hug and celebrate each chemo as a major achievement!!! X
Posts.Title: PICC line or not?

Posts.Content: Carol hope this is resolved painlessly meanwhile try to have a piccline put in before your next chemo as my concern is to have chemo without one (straight into your vein) perhaps I shouldn’t say anything as I don’t know what cancer or chemo you have nor am I  in any way qualified. I only can speak from my experience, it is totally unnecessary for things to go wrong but they do ☹️ Chemo has to be administered with extreme caution and problems happen very quickly which take a long time for you to recover !!!!  Every drop of good health and energy you have will be needed to deal with a perfectly administered chemo,  not wasted on recovering because it went wrong ....hence why they use a picc line.  All the very best and speak up with your concerns otherwise the nurses think all is well, you are one brave lady to inject your stomach my son had to do mine. My warmest hug to you  Mfx
Posts.Title: PICC line or not?

Posts.Content: Hello Margr I had similar to you all Chemo doctor gave me Hypromellose Eye Drops work a treat.  I have always had sensitive eyes so always used products by Maval and I wrote to them asking if they had any advice on nails and eye products that were good for chemo patients and they have sent me a booklet on how to take care of nails eyebrows and eyelashes while on Chemo with their products that are chemically free (it's a Swiss company  John Lewis sell it and you can get it on line) and its not too expensive compared to some. That reminds me need to do my nails as I have finished 3 FEC and yesterday had my !st T and apparently the nails get effected by light and can get painful. All the very best  Marie-Francoise
Posts.Title: lashes

Posts.Content: Hi there,  Go to the nearest park nobody around ....good ..... give yourself a lovely long scream you could even ask your grandchild if under 5 see who could scream the loudest then give each other a great big hug and laugh out loud.  Yes you have joined the club that no one wants to join and yes each journey is different but we are all here for you and wish we could give you a supportive hug  Now you have to request from everyone (very difficult) but if everyone mucks in they will have grandma back on track might be a little slower ‍♀️ I’m four years on doing good but still remember crying without shame down Charing Cross road when I was first diagnosed, since then I’ve made lots of friends in this club and my children have been my support, lifeline, held my hand and kicked my but in the nicest way. Give them a chance and you can all do this together and still coo and adore the little bundle to be born and your daughter will find happiness and your grandchildren will still hold your hand. Waiting is the worst as we fear what will happen if it happens!!!!  You have courage as you stopped lurking and we will answer your questions and support you.   You now must listen to your body and learn to say no I’m a little tired, or  Yes would love to but will need a little help.  Take care and let us know how you get on. Big gentle hugs
Posts.Title: I’ve been lurking.....

Posts.Content: Your welcome TraceyBB. Regarding your travel insurance I have an annual policy not sure if this would apply to you but I found out that as I had booked my trip prior to being diagnosed with cancer I would be covered for 45 days from date of travel. So was able to go insured ! Hope you have a good trip, it always helps recovery. Marie-Francoise
Posts.Title: Mastectomy and LD flap reconstruction

Posts.Content: Not sure this will help I had booked a trip to Australia prior to be diagnosed with breast cancer. I had a mastectomy + re-constructive surgery  on the 2nd December had to reschedule 18th Dec booked flight to 30th December, as I had a build up of fluid which my surgeon aspirated out but soon had another build up.  My Oncologist advised me that if you continually aspirate your lymphatic system it does not learn to operate, as it should!!! "Get plenty of rest with a pillow under your arm pit, also keep the pillow under your arm on car journeys, drink gallons of water, gently massage the effected breast in a circular motion going upwards towards the neck. " (I found the instructions on YouTube.) It worked and flew to Australia, again with a pillow under my armpit! I will be honest I travelled with my daughter who made sure I didn’t carry anything. Three weeks later returned nervously home on my own!!!! All went well and passengers sitting next to me couldn’t have been kinder once I explained why I could not climb over them to get to the aisle. I made sure I took the painkillers (paracetamol) at regular intervals with food, during the flight. I went for a walk up and down the aisle to prevent thrombosis + also wore flight socks. I did not have the same for my arm so I can't  comment.  I also kept that arm close to my body and tried not to use it. I really hope this helps because the holiday really helped with my recovery and strong enough for Chemo, which started a few days after my return.   All the very best  and have a wonderful holiday Marie-Francoise
Posts.Title: Mastectomy and LD flap reconstruction

Posts.Content: Hi, hope your first chemo was as comfortable as possible you will feel not as vibrant as normal but as they give you lots of additional drugs like steriods, anti sickness drips with your chemo,  the next few days you may be surprised by how much better you feel. But!!!  Warning!!! Keep taking your anti sickness tablets....I didn't and was so sick was walking around with a bowl! not nice soon l learnt my lesson.  Have cream crackers at hand and bland children's food is good. Make a game of putting toys away they soon learn its makes mummy sooooo happy. Rest whenever you can difficult with children but I am sure they love a little down time with mummy . Accept help Always and learn to ask even unloading dishwasher or washing up they may not do it your way but its done! I found/find that difficult but getting better. Never hoover!!! It makes your breast swell another lesson learnt my surgeon and children were not impressed. Never care heavy items including little children love lots of gentle cuddles and it's soooooo good for you. Chemo is your protecter and friend so that you have an amazing future. YesterdayI  had  my first Herzeptin no problem. Today  T part of the FEC&T I have finished FEC during which I learnt what my body  didn't like about the chemo and adjusted my life style  but all was surprisingly ok. Everyone is so different but reading different experiences an tips has made my chemo a lot easier to cope with and I hope it continues. Today I am celebrating I am over 66% of the treatment. You are down one yehhhh. you deserve a big cuddle. Listen to your body and do what you are comfortable with and I hope you have a pain free time with your Chemo wishing you all the very best. Marie-Francoise
Posts.Title: Coping with chemo

Posts.Content: Hi, whatever you are told its a shock to join a club you can't get out of, my understanding how you feel will not make it go away or necessarily  make you feel better, but...... yes I was in the same situation with the same anger and frustations but the kindness of my friends and especially my children (I live on my own) carried me through the surgery and four weeks later I was wearing a swimming costume (even with minus one breast M&S do amazing post surgery ones) on a Sydney beach. I had booked to visit my daughter before I was diagnosed. On holiday I continued to rest, slowly recover and I had a great time. Then sadly flew back home on my own...... but I was all the stronger for the chemo.   It was truly the best thing I could have done, so I am wishing you the very best..... you've done the anger put it behind you...... you need all the positivity ahead of you. Sending you a great big gentle hug to you all xxx
Posts.Title: scared and angry

Posts.Content: Hi Andrea ok you have joined the club nobody wants to be in, but a club where everyone has their own experience with this yucky problem, but  you are sure to get the most amazing support and joining this forum enables you to understand slowly what is relevant to you and so many people will be there to hold your hand throughout your treatment. On reading your letter these are a few things perhaps that may help. On your next appointment record your consultation ask your surgeon first, mine was so happy I did because like you I couldn't remember what was said on my first appointment, My family and I were able to listen to it piece by piece and understand better the diagnosis and proposed treatment. Like you I am HER2+ so my chemo was FEC&T: 3 x FEC .....it was ok felt sick initially but my assigned Breast Care Nurse soon gave me drugs to take care of that. 3 x T (docetaxel also called Taxotere ®) + 3 xHerceptin  via a picc line (which your surgeon will have his special place to put it mine was put under my bra some people have it there arm or chest.) Now that my FEC&T is complete I have 5 x Herceptin via an injection in the top of my leg into fat area and it doesn't hurt and I am not having side effects fantastic. I few more and then that milestone is reached. I used a cold cap throughout it adds on a few hrs extra for each chemo but I kept a lot of my hair, it does get thinner but if you have thick hair its not noticeable. I finished 2mnths ago chemo and have short but a full head.  Use dark nail varnish as some chemo reacts with light and damages your nails "Mavala" have fantastic advice sheet and I used their products which is for cancer patients and it worked. My daughter and I did each others nails. You will get tired so its fantastic that your family are so supportive as you will need them and it helps them to be part of you getting better.  Your daughter can help by washing your hair as its difficult after you have surgery .  Ask your son for help so he feels part of your recovery even if its doing his homework near you to keep you company when your resting. My son used to work on his laptop near me while I rested I found it a tremendous comfort. As a mother we take care of our family  unfortunately this is the time you will on occasion have to listen to your body and accept the care from your family. Wishing you all the very best. A huge big gentle hug, wishing you and your family lots of courage and strength. Love Marie-Francoise
Posts.Title: New Person!!!

Posts.Content: Hi Andrea ok you have joined the club nobody wants to be in, but a club where everyone has their own experience with this yucky problem, but  you are sure to get the most amazing support and joining this forum enables you to understand slowly what is relevant to you and so many people will be there to hold your hand throughout your treatment. On reading your letter these are a few things perhaps that may help. On your next appointment record your consultation ask your surgeon first, mine was so happy I did because like you I couldn't remember what was said on my first appointment, My family and I were able to listen to it piece by piece and understand better the diagnosis and proposed treatment. Like you I am HER2+ so my chemo was FEC&T: 3 x FEC .....it was ok felt sick initially but my assigned Breast Care Nurse soon gave me drugs to take care of that. 3 x T (docetaxel also called Taxotere ®) + 3 xHerceptin  via a picc line (which your surgeon will have his special place to put it mine was put under my bra some people have it there arm or chest.) Now that my FEC&T is complete I have 5 x Herceptin via an injection in the top of my leg into fat area and it doesn't hurt and I am not having side effects fantastic. I few more and then that milestone is reached. I used a cold cap throughout it adds on a few hrs extra for each chemo but I kept a lot of my hair, it does get thinner but if you have thick hair its not noticeable. I finished 2mnths ago chemo and have short but a full head.  Use dark nail varnish as some chemo reacts with light and damages your nails "Mavala" have fantastic advice sheet and I used their products which is for cancer patients and it worked. My daughter and I did each others nails. You will get tired so its fantastic that your family are so supportive as you will need them and it helps them to be part of you getting better.  Your daughter can help by washing your hair as its difficult after you have surgery .  Ask your son for help so he feels part of your recovery even if its doing his homework near you to keep you company when your resting. My son used to work on his laptop near me while I rested I found it a tremendous comfort. As a mother we take care of our family  unfortunately this is the time you will on occasion have to listen to your body and accept the care from your family. Wishing you all the very best. A huge big gentle hug, wishing you and your family lots of courage and strength. Love Marie-Francoise
Posts.Title: New Person!!!

Posts.Content: Hi Mel, just read your post you seem to have got a lot stronger since post surgery well done. Its a tough road to walk alone. You are about to start FEC chemo have you been offered the cold cap? If you are it might be something to consider as I went through it and now post chemo FEC&T have a nice little cap of hair and my wig has been worn twice in a vain attempt to take it out, it looked sad sitting in the box). There are a few points that will help with the process: Take painkillers before starting it eliminates headaches that some people get for the first 20mins. Wash hair with very chemical free shampoo (rosemary shampoo  by loreal is great as it stimulates  hair growth) Wash hair in as cool water .... as you can bear,  ok in summer. Avoid getting your head hot. It does add extra time to the chemo session. (It will depend on which machines your hospital use) Looking back it was a hassle but Im so happy my children encouraged me. Word of warning some hair does fall out so don't panic or get upset (like I did) but if you have thick hair your fine.  My hair was very fine. Whatever you decide big gentle hug and all the best with FEC. Marie-Francoise
Posts.Title: Chemo starting

Posts.Content: Hi there, letrozole makes people very nervous and some oncologist will insist each brand is the same but so many react to the compound it’s in, many are diary powder so if you have allergies to diary you will react. I reacted badly so my GP prescribed Norvatis Uk Femara as he put it it’s cheaper to have you well. So talk to your GP keep a diary of any side effects, and hopefully he will be as understanding or ask you chemist to order the brand that your body can tolerate.  Im afraid it’s a learning curve to what each individual can cope with but you have done so well had to tolerate with so much just be strong and ask for what you feel is good for you  I really wish you the very best of health.
Posts.Title: supply of accord (Letrozole)

Posts.Content: Moony I couldn’t agree with you more, I know it’s difficult at first but we generally go through so much and by the time we get to the letrozole bit many have lost their oomph and we accept but this is the time we need to get strong once again ! And say I need this brand doctor and to the pharmacist “you haven’t got it in stock would you mind ordering this brand and let me know when it comes in” trust me they usually get it in the next day, if they can’t go to another chemist, my chemist and I hug each other as she sees how much I’ve improved, my son noticed and pointed out they see so many who don’t do so well it must be nice for them to see good results.  So everyone be strong and make a chemist smile  big gentle hugs  mf
Posts.Title: supply of accord (Letrozole)

Posts.Content: Hi like london Lass I went to Trendco at 64 Westbourne Grove London W2 5SH Tel: 0207 221 2646 they were brilliant they also do them on NH afterwards I went to Trevor Sorbie in Convent garden and had it styled for free as he runs /teaches hairdressers to style wigs for Cancer patients it was so beautifully done and they treat you with such dignity although I felt very tearful initially by the end it gave me the strength to march out of the salon with my head held high feeling so much better.  So wishing you all the very best ( the cold cap didn’t work very well on me although I kept doing it at every chemo I said a tearful bye bye to my hair every time I took a shower) Now it’s all over and I have my wonderful hair back and the wig is back in the box . A big gentle hug  Mfx
Posts.Title: Wig shopping advice

Posts.Content: Hello Chaz, I think Jude has written exactly what I was going to, I have had similar diagnosis as Jude, So lets get through the lumpectomy first part surgeon has to make sure they have a lovely clear margin all round lump they are pretty good about that. Before you go in for surgery they put a blue dye into the lymph path near were effected area and that helps the surgeon, they took three nodes out of mine.....node 1 had little cancer cell....node 2 had some pre cancer cells......node 3 was clear yehhhhh.  Mine once removed were tested imiddiately, and he didn’t remove any more. I wish you all nodes nice and clear. Mine were tested immediately to see if the surgeon needed to remove more. As he said last one looked clear so rest remain. You will get an absolute result a week later after they go to the labs for thorough check. You have a scar not too big and little drain which will be removed usually before leaving hospital but that depends how long you stay in. Now this is the best advice I was given: Exercise…gently ….a little and often .... Lift effected arm to put behind your head that was our salute to our surgeon ….all his patience had to do this, this made your lymphatic system work again or your breast swell not nice and oh very painful, but if you get that just gently massage upwards towards the collar bone. I learnt a lot from YouTube and the Macmillan leaflets. Bras to buy I bought expensive post surgical bra oh boy very uncomfortable!!!! Easy for the surgeon to put on though.  But after a few days it caused blisters so was immediately put on antibiotics.  On advice by experienced patient was told get M&S tee shirt soft bra that the stitching is so smooth, I stepped into mine and pulled them upwards they are £12 for two, beige, white and black, not exciting colours so I ordered some on line but the stitching hurt!!!! I wear mine 24/7 and I am a size 38B, can’t wait to wear pretty ones.  But they have been comfortable and easy for my chemo admin as my pic line is under my breast. Now next part chemo I was reluctant to go through chemo as I had been given all clear. Basically it gives you a higher percentage of not getting it again or zapping the  nasty odd cell has gone for a walk about to do damage elsewhere! Your surgeon and oncologist will talk to you through it and which one is the best for you. they can only do this accurately after your removed lump and nodes have been analyzed but you will get lots of support and statistics.   I think that is enough for now, remember you are unique and your treatment will be especially for you, …..aftereffects …. your body will let you know always listen to it .… remember pain management you get no medals for pain ….there are many of us who are happy to help.   Wishing you all the very best and hope it’s a tiny little lump. Get plenty of rest…. no lifting anything …….say yes to ALL help. It will soon be over. Thinking of you and let me know how you get on. Marie-Francoise.
Posts.Title: When and why would you have chemo..

Posts.Content: I’m in the same position my oncologist and my GP both have given me so much support. They changed my letrozole prescription to Femara after I was so ill with the generic tablet I tried many, but I swelled could barely move and had upset stomach.  Each time I pick up my prescription from Boots who specially order it for me and then text me.  I say a BIG thank you   (I’ve had chemists refuse the prescription) I know I’ve done very well but that is all down to my health team and in return I enjoy and make the most of every great day I have.  I wish all my fellow BC on letrozole the very best holidays and support from everyone around them.
Posts.Title: Letrozole issues AGAIN! Need advice
